content: Economists debate whether the technique to correct economic figures for seasonal effects might be distorting the true picture about the U.S. economy.
Researchers are torn about how best to measure the effect that a spate of new state laws requiring identification from voters will have on turnout and on the election.
This week's news about the rise of 'nones' -- Americans unaffiliated with religion -- stems from a big increase in U.S. polling about religious identity, belief and practice.
When political polls survey more members of one major party than the other, is that a sign that the poll is flawed, or that voters have shifted between parties?

Twitter is reporting stats on tweets per minutes for everything from the Olympics to political conventions to football refereeing controversies. But some researchers question whether the data are meaningful.
How political scientists estimate the likelihood that a state's voters can swing the presidential race, and how their findings might discourage you from going to the polls.
A new book argues that by omitting prisoners from their pool of respondents, major federal surveys are painting an unrealistically rosy portrait of the social standing of young black American men.
Several studies suggest election fraud is rare. Advocates on either side of the debate on voter-ID laws disagree about why that is, and whether the numbers matter.
Crime reports don't agree with surveys, and surveys don't agree with each other. Counting pregnancies that result from rape proves even more challenging.
Mega-event organizers and host cities often release big estimates of economic impact. Some economists say these projections too often prove to be overly optimistic.
